reviews.review_msg:
This is a hard course. Lots of time will be spent on the HW. Ranging from 10 to 30 hours per HW. Form groups to reduce workload or solo for better knowledge.

Each HW progressively gets more difficult. Start early. Not necessarily hard theoretically.

Anoop cares that everyone succeeds and is available for questions. Would recommend.

379 is tough but worth it. We built a custom compiler over 4 iterations (30hrs each) with a contest at the end. Anoop's grading criteria is clear, projects are group-based, lectures are recorded, quizzes are online, and he replies quickly to questions. Would highly recommend Anoop, it is very possible to do well in this class and learn a ton.
He tries to be funny but he is not. I am sorry for any place in which Anoop is a comedian...
Great guy, very chill and approachable. Explains things in incredibly detailed fashion and gives solid examples. The homework for this course is pretty hard, so be prepared for that.

I found his 379 class extremely challenging. Exams are fair and he was quite lenient on the final but his homework is very hard. I only recommend this class if you are a very good programmer and understand abstract concepts very well. I easily spent over 50 hours on assignment 3.
Talk a lot of useless stuffs during the class, and very careless about the grading, you can even recieve more than 5 grading update notification for one milestone.

Homework mark is mostly known before submission (self auto-grader). Homework starts out easy (HW0,1,2), but becomes more confusing (HW3,4). Final exam reasonable. Grades are split fairly between homework, midterm/final exam. There are few reviews here because Anoop is awesome. Recommended.

Great guy, course was a lot of work but it was arranged in a way that made it fairly easy if you put in the time. The use of git to deploy assignments and fix bugs was great. Provided a generous amount of reference material to learn from. Compilers aren't really his thing, but he didn't do a bad job at all here.

This course is available for both graduate and undergraduate students but it is designed for graduate level. I would not recommend this course for undergraduate students. Prerequisite of "completion of nine units in Computing Science upper division courses" is not enough to do well in it. Take this course if you like a challenge and self learning.

The course is very well organized, which walks you through basic algorithms with a few more steps exploration. Team projects have heavy workload but really prepare you with actual capability in performing AI research for NLP application. This is rewarding.

A bit of a mixed bag with Anoop, was willing to help you if you needed it both in and outside the lab. Promptly responded to questions on the discussion board but he seemed like he had a bit of a chip on his shoulder and could be quite snarky/combative combative. Tests were easy and marked automatically, basically pass/fail, which was ok I suppose.

Decided to punish the class this semester with exams. Normally this class is just assignments, since it's the lab component of CMPT125, and the workload is high.  Exams graded by a robot, so any tiny error gives you a 0.  Super awful prof. Stay away.

Amazing lectures, amazing professor. The final project is a working end-to-end translations system which you'd be developing throughout the semester in the form of assignments. The class is heavily applications oriented. I would take any course offered by the prof.

Anoop is definitely one of the best in CS at SFU. Classes are clear, the materials on the course website clearer! The assignments are tough, but absolutely helpful. The test framework and the leaderboard helps a lot. Project is really interesting.  He cares for the subject. And his comic gestures are a cherry on the top. Do take the course.

He is definitely passionate about what he is teaching; however, only take his course if he is your supervisor. The lectures leave you in a confusing state just because the course is normally filled with his grad students from his lab and he does not care enough for the people who take the class without having previous exposure to the subject.

Being a professor means teaching and evaluating students. Anoop has no idea about the 'evaluation' part. His exam consisted of 4 questions, 2 of which required learning his slides by heart and jotting down the formula. He does not test for understanding, just for parroting. The grade you get doesn't correlate with what you know. It's a disgrace.

Anoop is one of the best at SFU. His course website is great with very clear pdfs of his slides. Assignments are very well organized. He provides a test framework which helps a lot in trying to solve them. Very personable guy with a good sense of humor.

Compilers are hard. But anoop does it in a way thats manageable. Assignments take time and you need to spend a lot of time on them. But talking to my friends who took it in Surrey I spent significant less time on the assignments and felt I learned the same material.
Super difficult class with very time consuming assignments. He is passionate yes.  Somewhat helpful but 99% time is done plugging away at the assignments.
Firstly I like his sense of humour. Four assignments are a little bit time-consuming if you are not familiar with nltk. No final exam but a final project. Btw, his TA is quite helpful and nice.
Great professor!
He doesn't know how to explain things. He's comedian rather than a professor.

On one hand,he is a nice and funny person.on the other hand, he doesn't really teach you anything,or he doesn't know how to teach.Notes are confusing rather than enlightening.Instructi0ns for Assignments are vague, you have to guess what he expects you to do.That being said, he seems to be better than the other prof(Shermer) who teachs 379 tho

Explains very well, and definitely knows the material extremely well.  Be aware that assignments and exams will be very difficult and lengthy (in the case of assignments).  Start early, and do the work.
Great prof with great passion toward natural language processing.
Great instructor, but teaches difficult courses.  Updates class notes online regularly.  Not necessary to attend class, but will certainly help.  Easy to understand.
Writing a compiler is a fair bit of work so beware the assignments.  Was an interesting class with pretty good notes (although perhaps a little overemphasis on grammars --- his research focus)
Cares about the topic. He's funny and makes the lectures interesting. Nicely laid out assignments and will give more time to class if needed. Awesome Perl Teacher.
